A similar problem happens when you attempt to launch a config that references 
an non-existant jar (explicitly, or via a default classpath). An error is 
placed in the progress view in this case, and the launch aborts.

Steps to reproduce
* set up a project A, with a buildpath that references an external jar
* afterwords, delete the external jar
* launch a config associated with the project A with a default classpath

This means there's an error on the build path or runtime classpath (in this 
case, the buildpath, since the scrapbook uses the buildpath to generate a 
classpath). The workaround is to resolve the buildpath error.

Not sure what we should do in general - i.e. allow the launch to proceed, but 
log a warning, perhaps?

For now I have improved the error dialog to provide the underlying error 
message (i.e. missing a jar that is specified on the classpath).

I think it's best to show a warning and let the code run with the good part of 
the classpath. I (and maybe others) often want to evaluate some code that only 
uses the basic java packages and there should be a way to do it even if there 
are some problems.

Deferring. For now a more useful error message is displayed. Our APIs are 
designed to throw exceptions. It feels like this may require a larger design 
change than we can afford at this point in the 3.0 cycle.
*** Bug 58820 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

traces.message: The  archive: /org.apache.lucene/parser.jar which is referenced by the classpath,  does not exist.
